bibl.title: Despatch from R.Dorsey Mohew to W.F. Wharton, March 29, 1892
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.ab:
United States Commercial Agency Boma, Congo Free State (Now at Brussels) March 29th 1892
Mr. R.D. Mohew To Department of State
Subject: Arrival in Brussels visit to offices of the Congo State, and audience with the King of Belgium
Abstract of Contents Arrival in Brussels March 22, 1892 Visited Congo State Offices March 20th Recieved by the King March 26th.
div1.p:
Honorable William F. Wharton Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
Sir, I have the honor to report any arrival at this place March 22 at 6:30 p.m.
The next morning I called upon thr Hon. Edwin H. Terrell the United States Minister and also upon M. George W. Roosevelt United States Consul.

In the afternoon I called upon M. Edward Van Eslvelde the Secretary of the Interior of the Congo State and also upon the Count de Grelle. Roqier, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs of the Congo and by back of these gentlemen I was recieved in a must cordiel
manner

manner.
They expressed themselves as being qualified at the United States filing the vacancy caused by M.Taunts death, and offered me every facility for acquiring information back here and in the Free State.

M. Van Eslvelde has received orders for me to have any vacant quarters in the Govern- ment houses and also that I be taken into one of the vessels at Boma, until I can get my own house and that the State Doelors attend me in case of sickness.
The next day I recieved a notification from the Count de Grelle. Roger that His Majesty the King requested one to come to the Royal Palace at Brussels Saturday afternoon at half after three.

I presented myself at the
Palace

Palace at the appointed time and was must cordially recieved by His Majesty who office making com- pliementary remarks regarding the United States (to which I replied in a suitable manner I said he was pleased to see that a Bill had been introduced into the Senate making provision for a Consul General and Vice Consul in the Congo. He asked me if + thought it would become a law to which I replied that it was impos- sible to say.
He said every facility would be given me owed he hoped that my visit to the state would be productive of good results to its com- merce.

The audience lasted nearly an hour and in that timee I became thoroughly impressed
by

by the fact that His Majesty was perfectly familiar with every detail of the workings of the Government of the Congo State. It is stated here in Brussels that no move is ever taken without his knowledge and consent.
I am Sir, Very Respectfully Your obident Servant R.Dorsey Mohew Commercial Agent
